# Geo-spatial and Statistical Packages {.unnumbered}

A comparison of some key `R` and `Python` packages.

| Purpose | Package | Key Functions |
|--------|---------|----------------|
| **Vector data handling** (points, lines, polygons) | **geopandas** (Python) <br> **sf** (R) | `read_file()`, `sjoin()`, `to_crs()`, `dissolve()` <br> `st_read()`, `st_join()`, `st_transform()`, `st_union()`, `st_as_sf()` |
| **Raster data handling** (reading/writing gridded data) | **rasterio** (Python) <br> **terra** (R) | `open()`, `read()`, `mask()`, `warp.reproject()` <br> `rast()`, `vect()`, `crop()`, `mask()`, `extract()` |
| **Multi-dimensional arrays** (NetCDF, climate data) | **xarray** (Python) <br> **terra** (R) | `open_dataset()`, `sel()`, `mean()` <br> `rast()`, `app()`, `subset()` |
| **Geospatial xarray operations** | **rioxarray** (Python) | `open_rasterio()`, `rio.reproject()`, `rio.clip()` |
| **Vector-raster operations** | **xvec** (Python) <br> **rasterstats** (Python) <br> **terra** (R) | `zonal_stats()`, `extract_points()` <br> `zonal_stats()` <br> `extract()` |
| **Fast raster extraction to polygons** (area-weighted) | **exactextract** (Python) <br> **exactextractr** (R) | `exact_extract()` <br> `exact_extract()` |
| **Static visualization and plotting** | **matplotlib** (Python) <br> **ggplot2** (R) | `pyplot.plot()`, `pyplot.imshow()` <br> `ggplot()`, `geom_sf()`, `geom_raster()` |
| **Interactive web maps** | **folium** (Python) <br> **tmap** (R) <br> **leaflet** (R) | `Map()`, `Choropleth()` <br> `tm_shape()`, `tm_polygons()`, `tm_layout()` <br> `leaflet()`, `addTiles()`, `addPolygons()` |
| **Statistical modeling and econometrics** | **statsmodels** (Python) <br> **linearmodels** (Python) <br> **fixest** (R) <br> **pyfixest** (Python) | `OLS()`, `summary()` <br> `PanelOLS()` <br> `feols()`, `etable()` <br> `feols()`, `etable()` |
| **Google Earth Engine access** | **ee** (Python)\* <br> **rgeedim** (R)\* <br> **rgee** (R)\* | `ee.Initialize()`, `ee.ImageCollection()`, `ee.Image.reduceRegion()` <br> Download GEE as GeoTIFFs <br> R wrapper for GEE |
| **Animated visualizations** | **matplotlib.animation** (Python)\* <br> **plotly** (Python)\* <br> **gganimate** (R)\* | `FuncAnimation()`, `save()` <br> `px.scatter()`, `animation_frame=` <br> Create GIFs from ggplot2 |
| **3D visualizations** | **pyvista** (Python)\* <br> **plotly** (Python)\* <br> **rayshader** (R)\* | `plot()`, `add_mesh()` <br> `Surface()`, `Scatter3d()` <br> 3D maps and renderings |
| **Geographic utilities** | **country_converter** (Python)\* <br> **countrycode** (R)\* | `convert()`, `continent()` <br> Convert country names/codes |
| **Parallel processing** | **dask** (Python)\* <br> **doparallel** (R)\* | `compute()`, `delayed()`, `array()` <br> Parallel processing for R |

::: callout-note
Some of these Packages marked will not be used in this workshop but are useful for advanced workflows.
:::

::: callout-important 

Important packages for raster data in R.

-   `terra`: the best way of loading and processing raster data.
-   `sf`: the go-to package for dealing with polygons, lines and spatial points.
-   `exactextractor`: the quickest, easiest and most accurate way to calculate zonal statistics. It’s an R wrapper for the `exactextract` package (written in C++). It’s more accurate than ArcGIS, QGIS, and Python’s rasterstats package in calculating zonal stats.
-   `tmap`: quick and easy, and its “view” mode allows you to create interactive maps that are built on leaflet.
-   `ggplot`: the best package for building beautiful maps. Allows for more customisation than `tmap`.

There are also the following packages which we will not be using in this workshop:

-   `rgeedim`: provides the easiest way to download data directly from Google Earth Engine as GeoTiffs.
-   `rgee`: an R wrapper for Google Earth Engine, so you can run GEE commands in R
-   `gganimate`: a package that allows you to turn your ggplot2 graphs into gifs.
-   `rayshader`: create animated 3D graphs and maps in R.
-   `countrycode`: a useful package to automatically generate ISO codes from country names (and vice versa), assign continents to countries.
-   `doparallel`: my go-to package for parallel processing. 

:::
